quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: For me, analytics is a business impact driving function and not purely a service function, not just answering the why, but answering the, "What do we do now that we know this?"
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Reframes analytics as decision-driving (action-oriented) rather than a reactive reporting/service function.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Retention is a terrible thing to goal on. It's almost impossible to drive in a meaningful way in a short term. Ultimately, you want to find a short-term metric you can measure that drives a long-term output.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A counterintuitive metric-setting principle: optimize for controllable leading indicators that causally drive long-term outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Yes, you are a data scientist, but your goal is to figure out what's happening. And if that means that you're going to pick up the phone and call customers, then that is what you're going to do to roll up your sleeves.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Sets an expectation of extreme ownership: use any method necessary (including direct customer contact) to get to truth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We all know that your website shouldn't be a static asset. It should be a dynamic part of your strategy that drives conversions.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read
quotes.context: A clear mental model for treating the website as an active growth lever rather than a one-time deliverable.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: 54% of leaders say web updates take too long.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read
quotes.context: A concrete data point highlighting how common slow iteration is, framing speed of updates as a competitive advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Getting to market fast is a top priority for product teams, and the last thing that you or your developers want is to build document workflows from scratch. It's time-consuming, expensive, and distracts from core work.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization advice: avoid rebuilding commodity workflows that pull focus from differentiated product work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You could stitch together multiple tools and manage those integrations or you can use an all-in-one document SDK.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read
quotes.context: A practical build-vs-buy framing that helps teams decide between integration complexity and a unified platform approach.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The best part about Anvil is the level of customization their SDK provides.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read
quotes.context: A selection criterion practitioners can apply when evaluating tooling: flexibility/customization as a key differentiator.

quotes.topic_title: Analytics as a business-driving seat at table
quotes.text: For me, analytics is a business impact driving function and not purely a service function.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A clear operating principle for positioning analytics as a decision-driving partner rather than a support queue.

quotes.topic_title: Analytics as a business-driving seat at table
quotes.text: I think there are analytics teams at other companies where they are answering people's questions, maybe even through Jira tickets, we're building dashboards. That was never really of interest to me. That wasn't the team that I wanted to build.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A concrete anti-pattern (ticket-taking/dashboard factory) that leaders can explicitly avoid when designing analytics orgs.

quotes.topic_title: Analytics as a business-driving seat at table
quotes.text: For me, it's about finding opportunities, about having a point of view on the decisions that we should make, not just answering the why but answering the so what. "So what do we do now that we know this?"
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A practical decision-oriented framework: move from explanation (“why”) to action (“so what/what now”).

quotes.topic_title: Analytics as a business-driving seat at table
quotes.text: I strongly disagree. I believe a central model, a center of excellence is superior and I'm happy to talk about why, but that's something that I feel quite strongly about.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A contrarian org-design stance that challenges the common default of embedding analytics in business units.

quotes.topic_title: Analytics as a business-driving seat at table
quotes.text: We've tried it or I shouldn't... well, we've experimented in the past with the alternative, so putting it into a business unit and it's just much more problematic and I think the value you get from a central model is far greater than some of the things that you might lose.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: An experience-backed claim that centralizing analytics can outperform embedded models despite perceived tradeoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Centralized vs embedded data org model
quotes.text: So mostly it's in terms of reporting lines because I think on the goal side, that is something where we have the same goals that our partner teams have, and I think that that's actually an important part of a successful central model.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Clarifies that centralization can be about reporting structure while still aligning incentives and goals with partner teams—key to making a centralized model work.

quotes.topic_title: Centralized vs embedded data org model
quotes.text: So you'd have a bunch of smaller, of course, data teams that sit embedded within the functions. And I understand why business leaders like that. You're embedded within the function, so you're a part of the team. That ownership, that camaraderie that comes with that, I think you can solve for that.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Challenges the assumption that only embedded models create ownership/camaraderie, arguing those benefits can be designed into a central model.

quotes.topic_title: Centralized vs embedded data org model
quotes.text: So for us, we have a central analytics team, but we are divided up into pods that map perfectly with how product engineering, operations marketing are structured as well.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Gives a concrete operating model: centralized reporting with pod-based alignment to partner org structures.

quotes.topic_title: Centralized vs embedded data org model
quotes.text: And in order to earn their spot, that's the deal. We get the seat at the table and we need to earn it by bringing opportunities that we all can go and go after.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Actionable expectation-setting for data teams: partnership status is earned by proactively surfacing opportunities, not just responding to requests.

quotes.topic_title: Centralized vs embedded data org model
quotes.text: Oh, there's so many. Okay, so the first thing is a consistent and high talent bar.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Highlights a practical advantage of centralization: standardizing hiring/evaluation to maintain a consistent talent bar across the company.

quotes.topic_title: Benefits of centralization: talent, growth, consistency
quotes.text: Oh, there's so many. Okay, so the first thing is a consistent and high talent bar.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Highlights centralization as a mechanism to standardize hiring quality across embedded pockets of analytics.

quotes.topic_title: Benefits of centralization: talent, growth, consistency
quotes.text: And being able to evaluate candidates with that same bar, using our same rubric. You just get more consistent and higher talent in my opinion.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Actionable hiring practice: use a shared rubric to enforce a consistent talent bar and improve outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Benefits of centralization: talent, growth, consistency
quotes.text: So if you're siloed, you may be the most senior data person within... I keep picking on marketing. But you might be the most senior data scientist within marketing. Where do you go from there?
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A retention/growth argument against silos: functional embedding can cap career progression for top performers.

quotes.topic_title: Benefits of centralization: talent, growth, consistency
quotes.text: So you don't have sales that was as defined by one team and sales as defined by another team. You just have sales and everybody is using the same metrics, the same methodologies, and you're able to improve your methodologies with input from more people.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A concrete operating model benefit: centralized definitions prevent metric fragmentation and enable shared methodological improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Benefits of centralization: talent, growth, consistency
quotes.text: And rather than recreating the wheel, building the same churn prediction model on six different teams. You can instead build one and have the input of six different teams.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Specific example of duplicated work centralization avoids, while also improving quality via pooled expertise.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing reactive requests with proactive deep dives
quotes.text: You have to be very intentional to carve out time for exploratory work for deep dives because as you mentioned, there are always more questions and more work to be done than hours in the day.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A practical reminder that proactive analytics won’t happen by default—you must deliberately protect time for it.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing reactive requests with proactive deep dives
quotes.text: And so I think being intentional about it and setting goals for your team around finding these insights through self-directed work is an important mechanism for holding ourselves accountable to that goal because it tends to be the first thing that goes when you get a lot of inbounds, you're like, "All right, well, let's deep dive on something that I don't know if it's really something. It could be high ROI, it could be low ROI, I don't know."
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Introduces a concrete mechanism—explicit goals for self-directed insights—to prevent exploratory work from being deprioritized.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing reactive requests with proactive deep dives
quotes.text: So the expected value is lower than this known thing that I can deliver and make someone happy.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A counterintuitive mental model: reactive requests feel higher-ROI because they have guaranteed stakeholders, so exploration needs structural protection.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing reactive requests with proactive deep dives
quotes.text: We would do hackathons for our team to carve out days to just go and look into these really interesting things and find opportunities.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A specific, repeatable tactic for creating dedicated space for proactive deep dives.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing reactive requests with proactive deep dives
quotes.text: And I think we have the support of our business partners because so many great insights have come from these deep dives and it really has been some of the work that drives future roadmaps.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Highlights how to earn stakeholder buy-in: demonstrate that exploratory work produces roadmap-shaping insights.

quotes.topic_title: Hackathon case study: referral fraud discovery
quotes.text: And rather than just lowering spend on referrals and moving right along, we really wanted to understand what was happening.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Highlights a disciplined approach: investigate root causes before making budget cuts based on surface-level performance.

quotes.topic_title: Hackathon case study: referral fraud discovery
quotes.text: And so during the hackathon, we did a deep dive into referral. We actually tried referring each other. We tried committing referral fraud, creating new accounts to get around rules.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Demonstrates a hands-on methodology—simulate real user (and adversarial) behavior to uncover system weaknesses.

quotes.topic_title: Hackathon case study: referral fraud discovery
quotes.text: And what we noticed was that referral as a channel was a bit misleading when you would look at the average in terms of payback and that it was really a bimodal distribution and you had one group of really great consumers who were referring other really great consumers, and the payback on those consumers was really strong.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A concrete reminder to look beyond averages and inspect distributions/segments to find hidden structure and opportunity.

quotes.topic_title: Hackathon case study: referral fraud discovery
quotes.text: And so I think that's an example of a few things that we like to do at DoorDash. One being these deep dives and taking the time to really understand the problem and then ultimately make a bunch of recommendations for what we should do, including better fraud checks, caps on referrals, et cetera, et cetera. But also how the average can be incredibly misleading. And so looking at distributions and trying to break down what you're seeing to find ways that you can optimize in ways that you can gain in efficiencies.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Packages the playbook: deep dives → actionable recommendations, and a core analytic principle—distributions over averages—to drive efficiency gains.

quotes.topic_title: How data teams push back: trade-offs and prioritization
quotes.text: So because our goals are the same as our business partners, we're able to pretty easily say, "Hey, we've got a limited amount of time. These are our goals. What are the most important things that we are going to work on this week or this month in order for both of us to hit our goals?"
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A practical framework for pushing back by anchoring prioritization in shared goals and a fixed time budget.

quotes.topic_title: How data teams push back: trade-offs and prioritization
quotes.text: And so when something comes up to be able to say, "Hey, this data poll that you want me to do, is this more important than these other three things that I was going to be working on? Yes or no?"
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A simple forcing function that makes trade-offs explicit and turns vague urgency into a clear priority decision.

quotes.topic_title: How data teams push back: trade-offs and prioritization
quotes.text: So I think that that's definitely something I would recommend, which is always share the trade-offs. Don't suffer in silence with, "How am I going to do all four of these things?" Bring it up and say, "Hey, this is what I was planning to do. If you want me to do this extra new thing, then one of these other things is going to have to drop.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A repeatable method for avoiding overload: surface constraints early and require a de-scope when new work appears.

quotes.topic_title: How data teams push back: trade-offs and prioritization
quotes.text: Every once in a while you just throw one over and say, "You know what? This is quick. I'll do it." At least I do. I think sometimes just knock it out, build some goodwill.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A counterbalance to strict prioritization: selectively doing small asks can build trust and make future pushback easier.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for curiosity and real-world problem solving
quotes.text: You can't teach curiosity, or at least I haven't found a way to do it.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Highlights curiosity as a non-trainable differentiator to prioritize in hiring beyond technical competence.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for curiosity and real-world problem solving
quotes.text: Somebody who is just self-motivated to pull on the threads when they find them.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Gives a concrete behavioral signal of high performers: proactively investigating anomalies without being prompted.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for curiosity and real-world problem solving
quotes.text: One way you can do it through the questions you ask is have something that is not quite right within the case that you're presenting and see if people notice first and foremost.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Provides an interview tactic to test curiosity by embedding an intentional inconsistency and observing whether candidates catch it.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for curiosity and real-world problem solving
quotes.text: Typically, it's something actually from DoorDash history, like a real problem that we had to see how people can problem solve on the fly.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Recommends using real internal cases (not generic prompts) to evaluate practical problem-solving under realistic constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for curiosity and real-world problem solving
quotes.text: And seeing how people react to being told they're wrong is a really important signal in my opinion.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Emphasizes adaptability and coachability as key evaluation criteria—how candidates pivot when assumptions are challenged.

quotes.topic_title: Non-traditional path into data leadership
quotes.text: But I became a data scientist out of necessity. I completely self-taught in terms of SQL and Python and I did it because there was a need at DoorDash for someone to help figure out what the right goals were, how we set those goals, how we were performing different markets early in the DoorDash story, so 10 years ago at this point.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Highlights a practical path into data: learn core tools quickly to meet an urgent business need and define goals/metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Non-traditional path into data leadership
quotes.text: I think I just gravitated towards that type of work and Tony recognized that superpower in me even though I don't have that formal training.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Emphasizes that demonstrated impact and strengths can outweigh formal credentials when leaders recognize and sponsor talent.

quotes.topic_title: Non-traditional path into data leadership
quotes.text: But I think that that non-traditional background has been a great thing because I'm able to hire people who have the technical skills that I don't have, the folks with PhDs in statistics and the data scientists, machine learning and otherwise.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Offers a leadership model: complement your gaps by hiring deep experts rather than trying to be the most technical person yourself.

quotes.topic_title: Non-traditional path into data leadership
quotes.text: I am able to hire those folks and yet keep them really focused on driving business impact because my background was on the finance side, and so I've always been a pragmatist. And for me, the purpose of our team is to drive business impact.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Defines a clear operating principle for data orgs—technical excellence in service of measurable business outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Non-traditional path into data leadership
quotes.text: And so the mix between the technical skills of the smarter people that I've hired, the smarter than myself, and my grounding in driving business impact has been a really great partnership.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Captures a memorable team design: pair high technical depth with strong business pragmatism to maximize impact.

quotes.topic_title: Habits behind success: first principles and competitiveness
quotes.text: When you're at a startup and things are moving quickly and you see a problem, and I've always liked solving problems, so I was like, "All right, how do I solve this problem?" It was like, "Oh, well, I need access to the data. I don't have access to the data. All right, I'll ask an engineer to get me the data. Well, this isn't going to scale. I can't always bother an engineer, so how do I figure out how to get the data myself? Well, let's learn Python."
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Shows an iterative, self-unblocking approach: follow the bottleneck and acquire the next skill needed to scale your impact.

quotes.topic_title: Habits behind success: first principles and competitiveness
quotes.text: And then I think if you think about things from first principles about what you need right now in front of you to unblock yourself or solve a problem, and you just focus on that instead of thinking about a global org that you're trying to build.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A first-principles mental model for execution: prioritize the immediate constraint over abstract long-term structure.

quotes.topic_title: Habits behind success: first principles and competitiveness
quotes.text: So for me, it was always about solving the problem in front of me the best way I could. And if that meant I needed to hire an engineer to report into me through the finance org, then that was what we were going to do and nobody was going to tell me I couldn't do it.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Illustrates pragmatic org-building: do what’s necessary to solve the problem, even if it breaks conventional reporting lines.

quotes.topic_title: Habits behind success: first principles and competitiveness
quotes.text: I think I'm competitive. I think that's a trait that you find in a lot of early DoorDash folks and current DoorDash folks, to be honest, just wanting to win and being willing to do whatever you need to win. So roll up your sleeves, do something that's not your job.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Actionable career advice: adopt a “do what it takes” mindset and take on work outside your formal scope to drive outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Habits behind success: first principles and competitiveness
quotes.text: I think back to early days of taking out the garbage on Saturday nights because it needed to get done.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A concrete example of high-ownership culture: no task is beneath you if it removes friction and helps the team win.

quotes.topic_title: Early DoorDash stories and customer-first culture
quotes.text: And yet in the morning when we would go out, he was with us handing out promo codes because he was part of the team because he wanted to win. We wanted to grow the business.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Highlights a culture of cross-functional ownership where incentives don’t limit people from doing whatever drives growth.

quotes.topic_title: Early DoorDash stories and customer-first culture
quotes.text: So I think that that ownership, that extreme ownership of the outcome is definitely one of the things.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A crisp articulation of a scalable operating principle teams can adopt: optimize for outcomes, not roles.

quotes.topic_title: Early DoorDash stories and customer-first culture
quotes.text: The first time I went there, there was a huge site outage and the whole company, it was like 20 people at the time, the whole company jumped online to do customer support, to answer the phones, to make sure that folks were getting refunds for orders that weren't going through, make sure the orders that were out there were getting delivered, just dropped everything and hopped on to do support.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A concrete incident-response model: during major failures, everyone swarms customer support to protect trust.

quotes.topic_title: Early DoorDash stories and customer-first culture
quotes.text: And I think that night was one of the largest refunds as a percent of our bank account that we had ever given out.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A vivid data point showing customer-first decision-making even when it’s financially painful.

quotes.topic_title: Early DoorDash stories and customer-first culture
quotes.text: we just gave a lot of money back to customers because it was the right thing to do because our service failed and we wanted to do right by them.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A memorable principle for handling outages: default to making customers whole to preserve long-term trust.

quotes.topic_title: WeDash program and building empathy across marketplace
quotes.text: But four times a year all the employees go out and go dashing or do customer support, and it's part of our culture that I love.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A concrete operational cadence for building customer empathy by requiring everyone to spend time in frontline roles.

quotes.topic_title: WeDash program and building empathy across marketplace
quotes.text: And it's important because you get to use the product, you build empathy with all the audiences.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A simple mental model: direct product use across roles creates empathy across the marketplace’s different stakeholders.

quotes.topic_title: WeDash program and building empathy across marketplace
quotes.text: But being able to go and understand what it's like to go out dashing and when you're in the restaurant going and talking with merchants and seeing the experience from their point of view, I think it's just incredibly important.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Highlights the value of experiencing the workflow end-to-end (dasher + merchant) rather than relying on secondhand feedback.

quotes.topic_title: WeDash program and building empathy across marketplace
quotes.text: And of course we find a lot of bugs like, "Hmm, this doesn't work the way it should, let me report this."
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Shows a practical benefit of frontline rotations: they function as a systematic way to uncover and report product issues.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: There's a world where your CRM is powerful, easily configured, and deeply intuitive.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A clear product vision statement that sets a practical bar for what “good” tooling should feel like for teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It syncs with your data sources, easily configures to their unique structures and works for any go-to-market motion from self-serve to sales led.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable evaluation checklist for CRMs: integrations, flexibility to match your data model, and fit across GTM motions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The next era of companies deserves more than an inflexible one-size-fits-all CRM.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A contrarian push against defaulting to legacy “standard” tools when your company’s structure and workflows are unique.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I want to come back to a thread, something you mentioned where you and a lot of the early team had felt extreme ownership over the company and that's why a lot of this stuff happened.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Frames “extreme ownership” as a causal driver of outcomes, teeing up a replicable culture-building discussion for founders and leaders.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Is there anything that you think that the early team did to create that or is it hiring, just pick people that will have that feeling already, or is cultural?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic question that breaks ownership into levers leaders can act on: hiring vs. environment/culture design.

quotes.topic_title: Instilling extreme ownership in data teams
quotes.text: But I think even today I expect of my team that same extreme ownership over the outcomes.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Sets a clear leadership expectation that “ownership” is measured by outcomes, not tasks, and must be continuously reinforced.

quotes.topic_title: Instilling extreme ownership in data teams
quotes.text: And so I'm more interested in our team figuring out how to solve a problem than the box that someone fits in like, "I'm a data scientist and so I only do these things."
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A practical hiring/management lens: optimize for problem-solving behavior over rigid role boundaries.

quotes.topic_title: Instilling extreme ownership in data teams
quotes.text: Right? It's like, "No. I mean, yes, you are a data scientist, but your goal is to figure out what's happening, and if that means that you're going to pick up the phone and call customers, then that is what you're going to do."
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Concrete example of extreme ownership: doing whatever method is required (even customer calls) to unblock understanding and decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Instilling extreme ownership in data teams
quotes.text: And that's where qualitative research is superior to quantitative research, it's asking for the context, to actually talking to people to figure out what was the motivation, what worked, what didn't for them.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Counterbalances data-first instincts with a clear heuristic for when to switch to qualitative methods to resolve “why” questions.

quotes.topic_title: Instilling extreme ownership in data teams
quotes.text: And so the team, data scientists included, just sat and made phone calls.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A specific, repeatable practice: embed direct user/customer contact into data work when experiments don’t behave as expected.

quotes.topic_title: Defining great metrics: inputs, simplicity, common currency
quotes.text: I've learned a lot of things about metrics, mostly from bad metrics. I actually think you learn a lot from picking the wrong metric. Ultimately, you want to find a short-term metric you can measure that drives a long-term output.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A practical metric-design principle: optimize for short-term measurable inputs that are validated to drive long-term outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Defining great metrics: inputs, simplicity, common currency
quotes.text: Retention is a terrible thing to goal on because it's almost impossible to drive in a meaningful way in the short term, and yet you want to be able to experiment and iterate quickly.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance to avoid goaling on lagging metrics that teams can’t influence quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Defining great metrics: inputs, simplicity, common currency
quotes.text: And so I always encourage folks, just pick something simple, even if it's not perfect and your composite would be more perfect. If people understand it, if they have an intuition around it, if it's something that people can talk about across the company, it's going to be a much better metric in terms of driving real outcomes than your made up composite score that nobody understands.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A rule-of-thumb for metric selection: prioritize shared understanding and usability over theoretical precision.

quotes.topic_title: Defining great metrics: inputs, simplicity, common currency
quotes.text: And so we spend a lot of time quantifying things in terms of a common currency. So for example, if I were to lower price by a dollar, what would I get in terms of, we'll say, volume? Well, what if I lowered delivery times by a minute? What do I get for that in terms of volume?
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A decision-making methodology for cross-team tradeoffs: translate disparate levers into a shared unit to compare ROI.

quotes.topic_title: Defining great metrics: inputs, simplicity, common currency
quotes.text: So we had a score for merchant health, which we tried experimenting with, which was a combination of factors that we had found would lead to a merchant being on the platform and getting an order. So we wanted to make sure that the merchant had active hours on the platform and had images and had a full menu that was accurate and robust. A number of different inputs. And we created a composite that weighted all of these different inputs. And then we were like, "What is our merchant health score?" And you were like, "It's 0.35. It's not 35%. So what is that, that 0.35? I don't know what it is."
quotes.speaker: Jessica Lachs
quotes.context: A concrete example of how composite metrics fail in practice when they’re not interpretable or intuitively meaningful.
